config.title: Workplace stress self-assessment
config.intro_title: Are you stressed by your job?
config.intro_copy:
There's a difference between stress and pressure. We all experience pressure daily and need it to motivate us. But too much can lead to damaging stress and statistics show that stress accounts for 40% of cases of workplace sickness in the UK. 

Take this test to find out if you're experiencing too much pressure at work.

q.title: New question
q.body: How do you manage your time at work?

a.body: My time is fairly flexible and I can have a say in deciding how I work and when to take a break
I have some say over the way I work but would like more
I don't have very much control over how I work

q.title: New question
q.body: When something is going to change at work, what happens?

a.body: I have plenty of opportunity to speak to my boss about any changes at work
We're always asked about possible changes at work before they happen but don't have much involvement in how decisions are made
We aren't told about changes and I'd find it hard to speak to my boss

q.title: New question
q.body: How do you get on with your boss or supervisor?

a.body: I can rely on them to help me out, encourage me and provide support
I can talk to them about something that has upset or annoyed me at work but that's about it
I don't get on with them very well and don't feel very supported

q.title: New question
q.body: How do you get on with the people you work with?

a.body: My colleagues will help me and are always willing to listen to any work-related problems
I don't think my colleagues offer me much support
I get on with them ok but wouldn't discuss any problems with them

a.body: People harassing you with unkind words or behaviour at work
Friction or arguments with your work colleagues

q.title: New question
q.body: Which of the following best describes how you feel about your role at work?

ib.title: More on control
ib.body: Having a say over the way you do your work is important. From being able to use your initiative and skills to do your job and developing new skills, to having a say about work patterns and breaks. Having control can help minimise stress.
ib.name: More on control

ib.title: More about change
ib.body:
Managing change well can help an employer to reduce or avoid stress within a workforce. The best ways to do this are to ensure: 
• employees understand the reasons for change 
• there is adequate consultation on changes
• employees are aware of any changes to their jobs
• employees are aware of the timetables for change
• support is provided for employees during change

Empowering individuals at work, giving them the right skills, and getting them involved in making decisions shows that their health, safety and wellbeing are being taken seriously. People who feel valued and involved in decision-making play a big part in a high-performing workplace. People will also raise concerns and offer solutions more often.
ib.name: More about change

ib.title: Talking to your boss
ib.body:
Open communication develops a positive culture and reduces accidents and ill health. It also improves overall efficiency and productivity. The law states that employers must consult employees regularly. 
If you find it difficult to talk to your boss, talk to your trade union representative or employee representative who can provide advice on a range of work-related topics. Alternatively, you can speak to your HR department.
ib.name: Talking to your boss

ib.title: More on relationships
ib.body:
Most of our waking hours are spent at work so it's important we have a good relationship with our colleagues.
Employers are encouraged to promote positive working relationships in order to avoid conflict and ensure fairness. Employers are also expected to deal with unacceptable behaviour such as bullying.
ib.name: More on relationships

ib.title: More about bullying
ib.body:
Bullying can make working life miserable. You can lose all faith in yourself, start to feel ill and depressed, and find it hard to motivate yourself to work. It's not always due to people's tribal instincts, or someone picking on the weak. Sometimes a person's strengths in the workplace can make the bully feel threatened, and that kicks off their behaviour.
Never ignore it. Talk to your colleagues, talk to your boss, talk to your family and, above all, talk to the experts. If you belong to a trade union, talk to them. They have well-established tactics for helping you bring the joy back into your working day.
ib.name: More about bullying

ib.title: More about roles
ib.body:
Employees should have a clearly defined role and be encouraged to talk to their line manager or boss if they are not clear about priorities or the nature of their job. 
This means you should be clear about what your job entails, what is expected of you and what you can expect from your employer. 
Team meetings can help to clarify your role and discuss any possible role conflict.
ib.name: More about roles

ib.title: More about demands
ib.body:
It's important that your line manager monitors workloads to ensure people are not overloaded and there are sufficient resources to do the work allocated. 
People should be encouraged to have a healthy work-life balance and take their annual leave and meal breaks. 
There should also be good communication about unplanned tight deadlines or any exceptional need to work long hours.
ib.name: More about demands
